customer_addr:

Panama City Beach, FL 32413

citations.narrative:
**Sections of the wall at the water level in the outdoor holding pool for sea lions has paint that is actively chipping. This
chipped paint can enter the water and impact the water quality or become an ingestion hazard to the sea lions.
**Along the far wall of the sea lion show pool, there is rust coming through the wall and running down the wall and into the
water. This section of the wall must be addressed to protect the water quality and keep the pool in good repair.
**There is cracked and broken concrete on the stage where the dolphins are being asked to, “slide out” onto the stage
during the show. Damaged concrete with rough edges can easily cause skin abrasions to the dolphins. These areas of
concrete must be maintained in good repair to protect the animals when they are asked behaviorally to come out of the
water onto the stage.
Facilities where animals are housed must be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury.

There is no shade provided over multiple dolphin pools or over the main show stage where the dolphins station for food
during training sessions with trainers. The lack of shade makes it necessary for the dolphins to bring their heads up out of
the water and feed directly facing the sunlight during the show and during guest interaction programs. Direct sunlight can
be uncomfortable for the animals and excessive exposure to sunlight has been linked to the development of eye
abnormalities in captive marine mammals. Several of the dolphins are currently on eye medications and their conditions
could be attributed to lack of shade and direct exposure to sunlight.
Steps should be taken to provide shade for marine mammals when they are being asked to interact with the trainers,
while holding their heads out of the water for training session or guest interactions, to avoid looking up into the sun. The
facility must provide the animals protection from direct sunlight for their health and wellbeing.
Correct by: May 24, 2024

Multiple metal bolts towards the bottom of the vertical support beams that go around the outside of the penguin habitat
are rusted. Some of the rusted bolts are actively flaking rust which can be a hazard if the rust impacts the water quality or
can potentially impact the integrity of the vertical beams. These rusted bolts need to be replaced to keep the area in good
repair for the safety of the penguins.
Correct by: May 30, 2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.101(a)(1)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
**Sections of the wall at the water level in the outdoor holding pool for sea lions has paint that is actively chipping. This 
chipped paint can enter the water and impact the water quality or become an ingestion hazard to the sea lions.  
 
**Along the far wall of the sea lion show pool, there is rust coming through the wall and running down the wall and into the 
water. This section of the wall must be addressed to protect the water quality and keep the pool in good repair.  
 
**There is cracked and broken concrete on the stage where the dolphins are being asked to, “slide out” onto the stage 
during the show. Damaged concrete with rough edges can easily cause skin abrasions to the dolphins. These areas of 
concrete must be maintained in good repair to protect the animals when they are asked behaviorally to come out of the 
water onto the stage. 
 
Facilities where animals are housed must be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury. 
3.103(b) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
There is no shade provided over multiple dolphin pools or over the main show stage where the dolphins station for food 
during training sessions with trainers. The lack of shade makes it necessary for the dolphins to bring their heads up out of 
the water and feed directly facing the sunlight during the show and during guest interaction programs. Direct sunlight can 
be uncomfortable for the animals and excessive exposure to sunlight has been linked to the development of eye 
abnormalities in captive marine mammals. Several of the dolphins are currently on eye medications and their conditions 
could be attributed to lack of shade and direct exposure to sunlight.  
 
Steps should be taken to provide shade for marine mammals when they are being asked to interact with the trainers, 
while holding their heads out of the water for training session or guest interactions, to avoid looking up into the sun. The 
facility must provide the animals protection from direct sunlight for their health and wellbeing. 
Correct by: May 24, 2024 
3.150(c)(2)

Facilities, general. 
Multiple metal bolts towards the bottom of the vertical support beams that go around the outside of the penguin habitat 
are rusted. Some of the rusted bolts are actively flaking rust which can be a hazard if the rust impacts the water quality or 
can potentially impact the integrity of the vertical beams. These rusted bolts need to be replaced to keep the area in good 
repair for the safety of the penguins.  
Correct by: May 30, 2024 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
